title: Mass Launched from Spring into Curve

content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A block of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed on top of an ideal spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is pushed against the spring, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="delta x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is released from rest, leaves the spring at the position shown in the figure, travels upward, and enters a semicircular track of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that has negligible friction. The block enters the track at point <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, maintains contact with the track, and exits horizontally at point <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a distance <math alttext="3 R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the point the block was released. The block then falls to the ground and lands a horizontal distance <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the end of the track. Express all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. The size of the block is much smaller than the radius of curvature of the track. (a) On the dot below, which represents the block, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the block while still in contact with the track at point <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. Justify your choice of vectors.
